newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Anti-Japan chants greet HK protest ship in Taiwan.
newsitem.headline: Anti-Japan chants greet HK protest ship in Taiwan.

text.p: A Hong Kong ship berthed in Taiwan early on Friday carrying the body of drowned activist David Chan and was met by raucous chants of "Down with Japanese imperialism!"

The tanker Kien Hwa 2 came back into port carrying 80 activists, reporters and crew back from a disputed East China Sea archipelago where Chan drowned on Thursday in a protest to claim islands back from Japan for China.
Chan drowned in a roiling East China Sea on Thursday after Japanese patrol boats thwarted his protest ship's bid to land on a disputed archipelago to claim it back for China.

When it put into Taiwan it complied with Taiwan's request not to enter flying the red flag of communist China, the island's arch rival since a civil war split them in 1949. A large flag that had flown on its bow was gone.

Even before the passengers could disembark, a crowd of some 200 Taiwan demonstrators chanted anti-Japanese slogans and waved flags of the island's exiled Republic of China government, which like Beijing claims the islands for China.
"Down with Japanese imperialism!" shouted dockside demonstrators from the opposition New Party, which favours Taiwan's reunification with China.
"Protect Chinese sovereignty! Protect the Diaoyus!" they chanted, using the Chinese name for the islands claimed by Japan since 1895 as the Senkakus.
